originalTitle: Chad shuts border with Sudan to stop conflict spreading
title: Keeping Everyone Safe! Chad Closes Border with Neighbour Sudan
content:
Hello everyone! It’s your friendly kid reporter here, bringing you important news from our amazing continent, Africa! Today, we’re talking about two countries that are neighbours, just like you might have a friend living next door. These countries are called Chad and Sudan.

A Special Line Between Countries!

Imagine your house and your friend's house. There's a line, maybe a fence or a street, that shows where one yard ends and the other begins, right? Countries have lines like that too! We call these lines "borders." A border is like an invisible fence that shows where one country stops and another country starts. Chad and Sudan share a very long border. They are right next to each other on the map of Africa. Did you know? Africa is a giant continent with many, many different countries, just like a big puzzle!

Friends, Chad and Sudan

Chad is a beautiful country where many wonderful children like you live, learn, and play. It's in the middle of Africa. Sudan is Chad’s neighbour to the east. It's also a big country with many people and amazing stories. Did you know? Chad is named after a very big lake called Lake Chad! It's an important lake for many people and animals.

Keeping Everyone Safe and Sound

Sometimes, grown-ups in charge of countries have to make important choices. They make these choices to keep all the people in their country safe and happy. Right now, there is some trouble happening in Sudan. We call this trouble "conflict." Conflict means that people are having big arguments or even fighting. This fighting is not good, and it makes people sad and scared. It's happening inside Sudan, not in Chad. Did you know? Everyone wants peace! Peace means no fighting, and everyone is kind and happy together.

Why Close the Door?

Imagine you are playing in your yard, and next door, there's a very noisy and messy game happening. You might want to close your gate or your door just to keep your yard quiet and clean, right? That's a bit like what Chad's government is doing. The "government" is the group of grown-ups who help run the country and keep everyone safe. Chad's government has decided to "shut the border" with Sudan. This is like closing the gate or the door for a little while. They are doing this because they want to stop the trouble, or "conflict," from accidentally spreading from Sudan into Chad. They want to keep Chad calm, peaceful, and safe for everyone who lives there, especially children like you!

What Does "Closing the Border" Mean?

When a country closes its border, it means that for a short time, it's not easy for people to travel between the two countries. It's like a pause button. People usually can't walk or drive across that invisible line between Chad and Sudan as easily as before. This isn't to be mean or unfriendly. It's a special step to make sure everyone inside Chad stays protected from any trouble next door. Did you know? Borders can also help protect special animals and plants in a country! Sometimes, scientists work together across borders to save animals.

Who Decides This Important Thing?

This big decision was made by the government of Chad. A special person called a "spokesperson" told everyone about it. A spokesperson is like a messenger. They speak for the government and tell the public (that's all of us!) what important decisions have been made. Chad's government spokesperson said very clearly that this decision is made to "protect citizens." "Citizens" are all the people who live in Chad – moms, dads, grandmas, grandpas, and especially wonderful kids like you! They want to keep all Chadian citizens safe from any harm or worry that the conflict in Sudan might bring. Did you know? Governments also help build schools, hospitals, and roads to make life better for everyone in the country!

What Happens Next in Chad?

For most children in Chad, life will continue as normal. You will still go to school, play with your friends, help your families, and eat delicious food. The government is just being extra, extra careful. This is like when your parents make sure you're safe by holding your hand when you cross the street. They are watching out for everyone to make sure no trouble comes to Chad from Sudan. It's a way of saying, "We care about you and we want you to be safe." Did you know? Many countries in Africa work together to help each other. They are like a big family!

Hoping for Peace for Everyone

Closing the border is a serious step, but it's done out of care and concern. Chad wants its people to be safe, and they also hope that peace will return to Sudan very soon. When neighbours have problems, sometimes it's best to take a little space until things get better. That's what Chad is doing. So, remember, Chad is closing its border for a little while, not to be unfriendly, but to make sure all the lovely people of Chad, especially kids like you, stay safe and happy. We hope for peace for everyone, everywhere! That's all for now from your kid reporter. Stay safe and keep smiling!
summary: Chad has closed its border with neighbour Sudan to keep its own people safe and stop any fighting from spreading into their country.
whyMatters: This is important because when there is trouble in one country, it can sometimes affect neighbours, and Chad's government wants to make sure all the children and families in Chad stay safe from harm.

title: A Story About Being Safe in South Africa
content:
Hello, My Amazing Friends in Africa!

Hi everyone! It's your friendly news reporter, here to share important stories from our big, beautiful continent, Africa! I hope you're all having a wonderful day, learning new things and playing nicely with your friends. Today, we have a story from a country called South Africa. It's a special place with lots of sunshine, amazing animals like lions and giraffes, and friendly people, just like you!

A Story About Being Safe

Sometimes, grown-ups do things that are not safe. And when that happens, the police step in to help. Our story today is about a grown-up named Bellarmine. The police in South Africa are asking Bellarmine some important questions. They want to find out what happened because someone got hurt. This grown-up, Bellarmine, is being asked about a time when a 23-year-old person got hurt badly. Getting hurt is never fun, right? It's like when you fall and scrape your knee, but sometimes grown-ups can get hurt much more seriously. The police want to know how this person got hurt and who was there. That's why the police are talking to Bellarmine. They are trying to solve a puzzle, a very important puzzle, to make sure everyone is safe and happy in South Africa. **Did you know?** Africa is the home to the tallest animal in the world, the giraffe! Their long necks help them reach yummy leaves high up in trees!

Why Do We Have Rules?

Do you have rules at home? Like "always share your toys" or "remember to say please and thank you"? What about at school? "Listen to your teacher" or "don't run in the hallways"? Rules are super important, aren't they? They help us all live together without bumps and scrapes and sad faces. Well, countries have rules too! They are called laws. These laws are like giant rules for all the grown-ups and kids in a country. Laws help everyone stay safe and make sure we treat each other with kindness. When someone doesn't follow these laws, it can make others sad or even hurt them. That's why these rules are so important for peace and happiness. When someone gets hurt, especially in a serious way, the police come to help. They are like super helpers who work to understand what happened. They want to make sure the rules are followed and that everyone can feel safe and sound. **Did you know?** South Africa has three capital cities! That's a lot of important places for grown-ups to work and make rules for the country!

The Police Are Here to Help

Imagine if you lost your favourite toy. You'd tell a grown-up, right? And they would help you look for it. Police are like those grown-ups, but for bigger problems! When a rule is broken or someone gets hurt, the police are there to investigate. "Investigate" means they look very carefully, ask questions, and try to find out the truth. In our story, the police are investigating because a person was injured. They are talking to Bellarmine and another grown-up to understand everything that happened. It's like being a detective! They gather all the clues to figure out what happened and why. They listen to people and look for important signs. It's super important to remember that the police are on our side. They want to keep everyone in South Africa, and all of Africa, safe. They want to make sure that people who hurt others understand that it's not okay to break the rules that keep us all secure. **Did you know?** Police officers wear special uniforms so you can always spot them if you need help! They are there for you to keep you safe.

Being Kind and Safe Together

This story reminds us all about how important it is to be kind to each other. When we are kind, we don't hurt others with our words or our actions. We share, we help, and we play nicely. Being kind makes our hearts happy and makes the world a better place for everyone. It's also a good reminder to always think about safety. Before you do something, ask yourself: "Is this safe? Will this hurt anyone?" If the answer is "yes, it might hurt someone," then it's best not to do it. Always tell a trusted grown-up if you see something unsafe or if you feel scared. They will always help you and keep you protected. Bellarmine and the other grown-up have not said anything about what happened yet. Sometimes, people need time to think, or they talk to their own grown-ups who can help them. The police will keep working hard to find out the full story and all the pieces of the puzzle. **Did you know?** The biggest waterfall in Africa is called Victoria Falls! It's super wide and makes a huge splash! You can see beautiful rainbows there!

What Happens Next?

When the police have finished their important detective work, they will share what they found out. If they think someone broke a big rule or law, then that person might have to go to a special grown-up place called a court. A court is where judges, who are like super-teachers of the law, listen to all the evidence and decide what is fair and right. This process takes time, just like it takes time to build a tall tower with blocks or for a flower to grow from a tiny seed. But it's important because it helps everyone understand that rules are there to protect us all. It helps to make sure that everyone learns to be safe and kind, and to follow the important laws of the land. We hope that the person who got hurt is feeling better soon and is healing well. And we hope that everyone in South Africa continues to learn and play safely, always remembering to be good friends to each other. **Did you know?** Teamwork makes everything better! When we work together and help each other, we can solve problems and make our communities strong and happy places for everyone to live.

Growing Up in Africa

Being a kid in Africa is so special! You are part of a continent filled with amazing history, beautiful nature, and vibrant cultures. It's a place where communities come together, where families share stories, and where the sun shines bright. We have so much to be proud of here. This story is just a little reminder that even in big, busy places, everyone needs to follow the rules of kindness and safety. It's up to all of us, big and small, to help make our homes, our schools, and our countries safe and happy places for everyone to grow up and thrive. Remember to always be brave, be kind, and listen to your trusted grown-ups. They are there to guide you and keep you safe. Thank you for listening, my wonderful friends! Stay curious and keep smiling!
summary: Police in South Africa are asking questions about a grown-up named Bellarmine because someone got hurt, reminding us all why rules and kindness are important for everyone's safety.
whyMatters: This story matters because it teaches us that rules are important to keep everyone safe, and if someone gets hurt, the police will help find out what happened and make sure fairness happens.

originalTitle: 'Affront to humanity': Sudan slams Uganda for hosting RSF paramilitary boss
title: A Big Chat in Africa: Sudan and Uganda!
content:
Welcome, Little News Explorers!

Hello, my amazing friends! It’s me, your friendly African news reporter! Today, we have an important story from our big, beautiful continent, Africa. It's like a puzzle about two countries, Sudan and Uganda, and how they are trying to be good neighbors. Let's learn together!

Meet Our Friends: Sudan and Uganda

Africa is so big, with so many countries! Today we are talking about two of them. One is called Sudan. It's a very big country in the north-east part of Africa. It has deserts and a very long river called the Nile. Imagine building sandcastles in the desert! The other country is Uganda. It is smaller than Sudan and it is in the east of Africa. Uganda has lots of green land and even big lakes! It’s famous for its beautiful mountains and friendly people. Both Sudan and Uganda are neighbors, just like you might live next door to a friend. **Did you know?** Sudan is home to more pyramids than Egypt! Imagine so many pointy shapes! **Did you know?** Uganda is known as the "Pearl of Africa" because it's so beautiful and green!

A Big Problem in Sudan

Sometimes, even friends have problems. In Sudan, there has been a big problem for a while. It's like two different groups of people in the same country are not agreeing. They are having a very big disagreement, and sometimes this means there is fighting. When there is fighting, it makes it hard for children to go to school, or for families to feel safe. Everyone wants peace, which means no fighting and lots of calm. It's like when you have a disagreement with a friend, but then you talk it out and become friends again. But this problem in Sudan has been quite serious for a long time. People there wish for peace every day. **Did you know?** When there is peace, everyone can play, learn, and grow up happily! That's why peace is so important.

Who is Mr. Dagalo?

In Sudan, there is one of the groups that is part of this big problem. This group is called the "Rapid Support Forces." That's a long name! We can just call them the "RSF" for short. The RSF has a leader, just like your class has a teacher, or a football team has a captain. His name is Mr. Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo. He is the boss of this group. The RSF is one of the groups that has been fighting in Sudan. So, when we talk about Mr. Dagalo, we are talking about the person who leads one side of the big problem in Sudan. **Did you know?** Leaders are very important people because they make many decisions for their group or country.

Uganda Had a Meeting

So, what happened? Well, our neighbor country, Uganda, decided to have a meeting. A meeting is when people sit together to talk about things. And guess who came to this meeting in Uganda? It was Mr. Dagalo, the leader of the RSF group! He traveled to Uganda and talked with important people there. It's like when you invite a friend over to your house to play. Uganda invited Mr. Dagalo to visit and talk. **Did you know?** Sometimes countries have meetings to try and solve problems or make new plans together.

Why Sudan is Not Happy

Now, here is where the puzzle gets tricky! Sudan, the country where the big problem is happening, was not happy about this meeting. Not happy at all! Sudan said, "Uganda, why did you meet with Mr. Dagalo? He is part of the group we are having a big problem with!" Imagine your two best friends. If one of them is upset with another person, and you go and play with that person without telling your friend, your friend might feel sad or upset, right? Sudan felt like Uganda was not being a good neighbor by meeting with someone they are fighting against. Sudan thinks Uganda should not have met with Mr. Dagalo. They felt it was not fair. **Did you know?** Being a good neighbor means helping each other and being kind, even when things are tough.

What are "World Rules"?

Sudan also said that Uganda was "flouting international law." That sounds like a very grown-up word, doesn't it? Let's make it simple! "International law" means rules that all the countries in the world try to follow. It's like the rules in your classroom, or the rules for a game. These rules help countries be fair to each other and try to keep everyone safe and peaceful. One of these rules is about how countries should act when there is a big problem, like the fighting in Sudan. Sudan thinks that by meeting Mr. Dagalo, Uganda did not follow these important world rules. It's like breaking a rule in a game, and then the other players get upset. **Did you know?** The United Nations is a big group of countries that helps make and follow these world rules to keep peace!

Let's Be Friends and Help!

So, this story is about how countries try to be friends and follow rules. When there is a big problem in one country, like in Sudan, other countries can help. They can help by sending food, medicines, or by trying to talk to everyone to make peace. But it's very important to be fair to all sides and follow the world's rules. We all want countries to be good neighbors, just like we want to be good friends at school. When countries work together and follow the rules, it helps everyone live in peace and safety. It helps children go to school and play without worry. **Did you know?** Many people all over the world are working hard to help bring peace to Sudan.

Always Choose Peace!

It’s a big world out there, full of interesting stories! Remember, even when there are disagreements, the best way is always to talk and find a peaceful solution. We hope that Sudan and Uganda can talk things out and keep working towards peace in Africa. Let's all wish for peace for all children in Sudan and everywhere! Thank you for exploring this news with me today!
summary: Sudan is unhappy because its neighbor, Uganda, met with the leader of a group that is fighting in Sudan, which Sudan thinks is not following important world rules.
whyMatters: It's important for countries to be good neighbors and follow rules so everyone can live in peace and safety, especially the children, and to make sure everyone is treated fairly.

originalTitle: Zelensky tells BBC Putin has started WW3 and must be stopped
title: News from Far Away: All About Peace in Ukraine!
content:
Hello, amazing friends! It’s your kid-friendly news reporter here, bringing you important news from around our wonderful world. Today, we’re going to talk about a country called Ukraine. It’s very far away from us, in a place called Europe. But even though it's far, what happens there can make us think about peace and kindness everywhere!

A Special Chat with President Zelenskyy

Imagine the leader of your country talking to a news reporter. That’s what happened recently! Mr. Volodymyr Zelenskyy is the brave leader of Ukraine. He sat down to talk with a reporter from a news company called the BBC. They talked in a special city called Kyiv. Kyiv is the biggest city in Ukraine, full of beautiful buildings and friendly people. **Did you know?** The BBC is one of the oldest and biggest news companies in the world! They share stories from everywhere, just like we're doing now! Mr. Zelenskyy was talking about something very important, something called a "war." A war is when countries fight with each other. It’s a very sad thing because it makes people unhappy, breaks homes, and stops children from going to school easily. No one likes war, especially not the children who live there.

What is a "War" and Why is it Sad?

A long time ago, about four years ago, a big country next to Ukraine called Russia started fighting Ukraine. The leader of Russia is Mr. Vladimir Putin. When countries fight, it’s like when friends argue, but much, much bigger and with serious consequences. Homes can get broken, and families sometimes have to leave their towns to be safe. It’s a very difficult time for everyone, and it makes people feel scared and worried. **Did you know?** Ukraine is famous for its bright yellow sunflowers! They grow everywhere and look like big, happy suns. They even make delicious oil from them! Mr. Zelenskyy talked about how this fighting has been going on for a long, long time – almost four years! Can you imagine something sad happening for four whole years? That’s why he wants it to stop. He said some very big words, like "World War 3." Now, that might sound a bit scary, but it just means he’s worried that this fighting could become a problem for many, many more countries around the world. But don't worry too much! Many good people and many countries are working very hard to make sure that doesn't happen.

Working for Peace, Not War

When Mr. Zelenskyy says things like "Putin must be stopped," he means that the fighting needs to end. He wants Russia to stop fighting Ukraine so that people can live in peace again. Peace means everyone can be safe, happy, and live in their homes without fear. Children can go to school, play with their friends, and families can be together. That sounds much better, doesn't it? **Did you know?** Our very own continent, Africa, is also full of countries that work very hard to bring peace and help people in different parts of the world. We know how important it is to live together peacefully! Many leaders from other countries, and many people like you and me, want the fighting to stop. They are all trying to help Ukraine and ask Russia to choose peace. They believe that talking and being kind is always better than fighting. Imagine if everyone in the world just chose to be kind and share! What a wonderful world that would be!

Why is This News Important for Us?

Even though Ukraine is far away, this news helps us remember how important peace is. It shows us that when people fight, it causes a lot of sadness. It also shows us that leaders like Mr. Zelenskyy are trying their best to protect their people and bring back peace. **Did you know?** The word "anniversary" means remembering something that happened a year ago. A four-year anniversary of a war is a sad reminder of how long the fighting has been going on. What can we do, as amazing kids in Africa? We can remember to be kind to our friends, share our toys, and help our families. We can also learn about different countries and understand that even if people are far away, they are just like us – they want to live happily and safely. Every little act of kindness and every wish for peace makes our world a better place. Let’s send our hopeful thoughts for peace to all the children and families in Ukraine. We hope that one day very soon, they can play and learn without any worries. And let's always remember to choose kindness in our own lives, every single day!
summary: The leader of Ukraine, President Zelenskyy, shared his hope for peace after four years of fighting with Russia, reminding everyone that peace is the best way forward.
whyMatters: This news is important because it teaches us about peace, kindness, and how leaders around the world try to help people live safely, even far away.
